Functional acidic sites can be generated in the structure of layered silicates by the isomorphic substitution of silicon by aluminum atoms, leading to suitable heterogeneous catalysts. H-[Al]-RUB-18 samples were synthesized with Si/Al molar ratios of 15, 30, and 60. Experimental characterizations showed that two different aluminum sites were obtained: one tetrahedrally coordinated (framework-Al), very similar to those found in microporous zeolites; and the other octahedrally coordinated, analogous to silanol groups (hydrated aluminol sites). Computational simulations based on Density Functional Theory (DFT) were used to test the atomic positions of these aluminum sites and confirmed, in terms of electronic energies, the tetrahedral and octahedral positions already predicted in the experimental characterizations. In addition, ethanol dehydration reaction was used to probe the acidic sites and evaluate the performance of the different [Al]-RUB-18 samples. Although a widely known reaction for zeolites and other porous solids, the chemical analysis in this work indicated that the Al-substituted layered silicates are promising candidates to be used in heterogeneous catalysis. The experimental catalytic data showed that the presence of aluminum atoms improved the reaction conversion. Moreover, MEP calculations also presented, in each step of ethanol dehydration, Alframework sites with the lowest electronic energy barriers. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Layered Silicate RUB-18 Catalysis Ethanol Dehydration DFT calculations Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrated layered silicates are solids whose crystals grow in only two directions [1]; these crystalline arrangements are usually called lamella, in this case being exclusively composed of SiO4 tetrahedra (Q4, (O4Si)4–Si) [2] connected through the oxygen atoms [3,4]). The surface of these materials is covered by silanol and silanolate groups (Q3, (O4Si)3Si–OH and (O4Si)3Si–O−, respectively) [2], commonly counterbalanced by hydrated sodium ions located in the interlamellar space [5,6]. Layered silicates are recognized by the reactivity of their silanol groups and flexibility of the interlamellar space, however, they present small surface area and low acidity. Their surface silanol groups are considered extremely weak Brønsted acidic sites [7]. Previous studies involving magadiite and Na-RUB-18 layered silicates showed that their acidity can be improved through the incorporation of trivalent atoms, such as aluminum [8–10]. In principle, the negative charge generated by these atoms can be compensated by a proton, configuring a conventional Brønsted acidic site. However, as layered silicates are primarily silica matrices, the challenge is to understand the structure and nature of the aluminum sites created, how they generate acidity, and the possibility of catalytic applications. Additionally, the dehydrated layered solids have smaller interlamellar spaces due to the removal of water and simultaneous closing in of the lamella, which makes access to internal sites difficult. It has been shown that this process can be reverted by the addition of water or ethanol to the solid [11]. Layered materials in the form of clays were used as catalysts in the early days of the petrochemical industry. Some examples are transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [12], layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [13,14], lamellar zeolites [15], aluminophosphates (AlPOs) [16]), and clay composites [17]. A few layered silicates have also demonstrated their potential as catalysts [8–10], as well as adsorbents [18] and ion exchangers [19]. [Al]-magadiite and [Al,V]-magadiite catalysts were recently employed successfully in the ethanol dehydration reaction [10]. Ethanol dehydration is a model reaction widely used when probing acidic sites and their accessibility in zeolites and other porous solids. The main product of this reaction, ethylene, is of interest to the scientific community and industry, especially regarding the conversion of bioethanol, which comes from biomass [20]. Conventional microporous catalysts have not been successful in processing large molecules from biomass due to the confinement of active sites in small pores and cavities and their difficult access. In turn, layered silicates have properties that make them attractive catalysts for this type of process, in particular the flexibility of the interlamellar space, which can be contracted and expanded according to the molecule hosted there [11]. Calculations based on Density Functional Theory (DFT) are an important tool to improve the structural characterizations of many families of layered solids. The solution of the Na-magadiite crystal structure and its thermal treatment was only possible recently, through a combination of 3D electron diffraction, Rietveld refinement, and geometry optimizations by DFT methods [21,22]. As already reported in many works, computational studies have provided information on layered double hydroxides [23–26], montmorillonites [27] and zirconium phosphates [28] with the analysis of basal spacing, spectroscopy, acidity, charge distribution, and thermodynamics properties. Additionally, energy barrier calculations can provide kinetic properties of chemical reactions and are of interest in this work. For example, DFT works indicated that dissociative chemisorption was the most probable form of adsorption of organic molecules on mixed oxides MgO(001), MgO:Zn(001), MgO:Al(001) and MgO:Al,Zn(001) surfaces [27,29]. According to Fonseca et al. [29], a comparative analysis of energies showed that H2S, CH3CH2SH, and CH3CH2OH presented better doping properties on all surfaces than molecular nitrogen species. In addition, MgO:Al(001) surface showed to be a better catalyst than the MgO:Al,Zn(001) for some reactions, such as ethanol dissociation. Computational studies of doped surfaces can also be useful to analyze acidic sites and improve surface-catalyzed processes. The possibility of preparing Al-substituted Na-RUB-18 and their pillared counterparts with the generation of intrinsic acidity was shown before [9]. Furthermore, the conversion of ethanol to ethylene was qualitatively studied through in situ FTIR experiments [9] on these solids. However, structural details as the most likely site of heteroatom incorporation, as well as its coordination and nature of sites are still lacking. Thus, this work aims at describing the structure of Na-[Al]-RUB-18 acidic sites by combining experimental results and theoretical calculations; in addition, the interaction of the acidic aluminum sites with ethanol and their role in the conversion to ethylene is also examined. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Syntheses The synthesis of the layered silicate Na-RUB-18 and the post-synthesis incorporation of aluminum into its structure producing Na-[Al]-RUB-18 followed the procedures described by the literature [9,30]. Solids with Si/Al molar ratios of 15, 30, and 60 in the synthesis were prepared. The processes employed high-purity reagents – distilled water, silica (Aerosil 200, Degussa), sodium hydroxide (Emsure), and aluminum isopropoxide (Alfa Aesar, 98+%). To obtain the acidic form of the samples, they were ion exchanged by dispersing the solids in a 0.06 mol L−1 HCl (J.T. Baker, 36.5–38.0% m/m) solution (0.3 L g−1). The system was kept under magnetic stirring at room temperature for 1 h. 2.2 Structural characterization The powder X-ray diffractograms (XRD) were obtained in a Shimadzu XRD-7000 diffractometer, operating with CuKα1 radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å), 40 kV voltage, 30 mA filament current, and a graphite monochromator. All measurements were collected in the 1.5 to 40° 2θ range, using a 2° 2θ min−1 scanning speed, 0.5 mm inlet scattering slits, at room temperature. The solid-state NMR spectra were obtained by loading the samples in zirconia rotors and using a Bruker Avance II 400 MHz spectrometer. The 29Si MAS-NMR spectra were collected at 79.49 MHz, using a 10 MHz spinning rate and a π/ 2 pulse (6.25 μs), with a 60 s delay, using kaolinite as the reference at −91.2 ppm. The 27Al MAS-NMR spectra were collected at 104.26 MHz, using a 10 MHz spinning rate and a π/12 pulse (0.35 μs), with a 2 s delay, using an acidic solution of Al(NO3)3 as the reference at 0 ppm. The crystalline habits of the samples were analyzed by a JEOL JSM-T300 scanning electron microscope (SEM), operated at an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. Before the analyses, the samples were dispersed in acetone and then deposited in a holder on carbon tape and mica, and covered by an iridium layer sputtered on a Bal-Tec MD020 instrument (Balzer). The Si/Al molar ratios were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF), using a Shimadzu-XRF1800 fluorescence spectrometer. A 40 kV rhodium source was used with a 95 mA current. The analyses were performed under vacuum, with the continuous rotation of the sample, 8° min−1, 0.1° steps. Fundamental parameters protocol was used to determine the concentration of the elements. 2.3 Acidic and catalytic characterization The acidic H-RUB-18 and H-[Al]-RUB-18 samples were analyzed by ammonia thermoprogrammed desorption (NH3-TPD). The curves were obtained using a Quantachrome TPD/TPR ChemBet-3000 instrument. Approximately 100 mg of sample were placed in a quartz reactor and treated under He flow (30 mL min−1) for 1 h at 250 °C. In sequence, the sample was cooled to 100 °C and saturated with NH3/He (4 vol%) for 1 h; the physisorbed NH3 was removed by He flow (30 mL min−1) for an additional 1 h at the same temperature. Finally, the sample was heated to 400 °C (10 °C min−1) under He flow (30 mL min−1) and the NH3 desorption was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The acidic samples were also tested using the ethanol dehydration reaction, carried out in a Microactity-Effi – PID Eng & Tech catalytic reactor; model MAEPGLIM3, for 75 h at 350 °C. The products of ethanol conversion were determined and quantified by a gas chromatograph coupled to a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 Ultra mass spectrometer, equipped with an HP-Plot Q column (30 m x 0.32 mm x 20 μm) and a BID detector. Approximately 100 mg of the sample were dried at 250 °C for 1 h under N2 flow (20 mL min−1). Finally, the temperature was adjusted to the experiment set and a He flow (20 mL min−1) was passed through a saturator containing liquid ethanol (EMSURE, ≥99.9%) with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 5828 h−1. Computational codes were available in the QUANTUM ESPRESSO package [35]. The exchange-correlation potential was described by the PBE functional [36], with the core electrons treated with a projector-augmented wave (PAW) [37]. The Kohn-Sham orbitals were expanded in a plane wave basis set up to a kinetic energy cutoff of 55 Ry and a k-point grid of 2 × 2 × 1 was used to sample the first Brillouin zone for all cells according to Monkhorst-Pack method [38]. The structures were simulated using a primitive unit cell of hydrated Na-RUB-18 (Na8Si32O64(OH)8·32H2O) reported in the literature [39,40]. For the Na-[Al]-RUB-18, the tetrahedral and octahedral aluminum atoms were inserted into the layered Na-RUB-18 at different available silicon sites. The sites were tested through the comparison of their electronic energies after geometry optimizations. Simulated XRDs were performed for comparison with experimental results. For the study of ethanol dehydration, simulated surfaces of H-RUB-18 and H-[Al]-RUB-18 were obtained by the delamination process from the layered materials. First, the species of the interlayer region were removed, and the charges of the silanolate groups were neutralized with hydrogen atoms, leading to acidic forms. Then, a single layer was selected with the insertion of a vacuum along the stacking direction of layers, which is, perpendicular to the c parameter. This vacuum was placed on the top of the surface to ensure that there are no interactions between the periodic images perpendicular to the surface. After that, an ethanol molecule was inserted into each surface and the dehydration reaction was performed similarly to the schematic mechanism already experimentally examined [41] (Fig. 1 ). The chemical reactions are shown below (R1–R4). As can be seen, the complete reaction leads to the formation of water and ethylene molecules (R1). First, when catalyzed by a surface, there is adsorption at acidic sites (R2) which was represented by H-[Al]-RUB-18–[HOCH2CH3](s). Then, the reaction can be analyzed in two steps: water elimination (R3) and ethylene formation (R4). The transition states along the minimum energy path (MEP) and the energy barriers of the dehydration reactions were obtained using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [42,43] with a path of 12 images by each step. 3 Results and discussion In principle, the idea of using a lamellar material as a catalyst crashes into the fact that the material has to be dehydrated before the reaction and this process of water elimination from the interlayer space causes the lamella to close in, making the interlamellar space very small for the molecules of interest to get access to internal active sites. However, Campos et al. [11] has shown that the interlamellar space can be reopened by the adsorption of water or ethanol and thus these molecules can enter and access the sites. These conclusions prompted the studies on the use of H-[Al]-RUB-18 for the ethanol dehydration reaction. 3.1 Structure and acidic sites characterization and ethanol dehydration performance The solids obtained in this work were identified by XRD and the patterns are shown in Fig. 2 . The patterns are very similar to those found in the literature [9] and confirm that the samples are crystalline solids and that the insertion of Al in the structure does not disturb long distance characteristics of the solid. Aluminum atoms were indeed inserted into framework sites, as shown by the 27Al-MAS-NMR in Fig. 3(B). In fact, tetrahedral sites are found in the three samples, regardless of the Si/Al molar ratios while octahedral sites are found only in the sample where Si/Al molar ratio was 15 on the synthesis mixture and 22 on the solid. As shown before in the literature [9] the insertion of aluminum into the structure does not disturb the silicon atoms in any important way: two signals of the well-known Q3 and Q4 sites are found at around −99 and −111 ppm in Na-RUB-18. The positions of the peaks are not changed with Al insertion however a minute decrease in the −111 ppm peak is observed and a general widening of the signal was observed. Thus, as before [9], crystalline lamellar solids are obtained containing tetrahedral Al sites in the larger Si/Al molar ratios and tetrahedral and octahedral sites in the samples prepared in the presence of larger amounts of Al. The results from the ethanol dehydration reaction over H-RUB-18 and H-[Al]-RUB-18 catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 1 , the last also presents the acidity data obtained from the NH3-TPD curves (Fig. S2). The performance of the Al-catalysts was significantly superior to that of the pure silica material, showing the role of aluminum incorporation as a viable way to generate acidic sites in the RUB-18 structure. Ethanol conversion was proportional to the aluminum content and, consequently, to the acidic sites, being very similar for H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 and H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18; which showed conversions of 83 and 80%, respectively. It is worth remembering that the first presents not only tetrahedral but also octahedral aluminum sites. After the integration of the peaks for tetrahedral and octahedral Al sites in the 27Al-MAS-NMR spectrum of Na-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 (Fig. 3 B, curve c), the fractions of octahedral and tetrahedral aluminum sites were found to be 23 and 77% of the total sites, respectively. With these fractions, a Si/AlTd equal to 29 can be calculated, very close to the aluminum content in the Na-[Al30_32]-RUB-18 sample, which presents only tetrahedral aluminum sites. Thus, it is possible that a limit of intra-lattice aluminum incorporation exists and is around Si/Al of 30. Higher aluminum concentrations probably give rise to surface hexacoordinated species as observed for Na-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 sample. The presence of the tetrahedral sites is associated with their slightly higher activity when compared to H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18, since, in terms of the framework-Al, the difference between them is minimal. The pure silica sample, even without structural aluminum, presents 15.5 µmol.g−1 of acidic sites. It is possible to relate this result with the ammonia adsorption on silanol groups present on the lamella surfaces. In this way, the H-RUB-18 catalyst exhibits some acidity, being able to convert ethanol to its main products. However, unlike the Al-catalysts, this sample showed greater selectivity to acetaldehyde, commonly favored by the presence of redox sites [44]. In the ethanol dehydration reaction, acetaldehyde can be obtained through the ethanol dehydrogenation mechanism, in which the oxygen atoms from siloxane groups are considered the catalytic sites [45,46]. Highly dehydrated silica is a well-known catalyst for ethanol dehydrogenation and shows an NH3-TPD profile similar to the H-RUB-18 sample, which may indicate that the oxygen of its siloxane groups may also be able to catalyze this reaction [45,46]. Other products from the ethanol dehydration reaction are ethylene and diethyl ether, whose formation is catalyzed by Brønsted acidic sites [41,47,48]. Both products are thermodynamically favored at intermediate temperatures (200–300 °C) [49], however, the ethylene formation is endothermic, while the diethyl ether formation is exothermic [49]. Thus, temperature increase usually favors ethylene and disfavors diethyl ether. For this reason, under the conditions studied (350 °C), ethylene was the preferred product for all catalysts, especially for H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 and H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18 samples, which showed 92% selectivity. In addition to both materials presenting higher aluminum content and, consequently, acidic sites, they show a significant fraction of moderate to strong acidic sites, as evidenced by their NH3-TPD curves (Fig. S2). All catalysts have maximum ammonia desorption around 180–200 °C (region of weak sites), however, these two samples show a shoulder from approximately 280 °C to 400 °C, centered at 320 °C (region of moderate to strong sites). Some works in the literature that correlate better performances of solid acidic catalysts concerning ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity with the presence of stronger acidic sites [50,51]. Over the 75 h on stream, it is possible to observe a slow decrease in conversion, which can be attributed to catalyst deactivation; ethylene selectivity follows this trend, while diethyl ether is favored as the reaction advances. The deactivation process most frequently associated with the ethanol dehydration reaction in acidic solids is the formation of light coke, carbonaceous and hydrocarbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface. With regard to the coke effect, the weaker acidic sites present a more satisfactory lifespan performance than the stronger ones [52]. In addition, there is strong evidence that weaker acidic sites are associated with diethyl ether catalysis, while stronger ones favor conversion to ethylene [53]. Thus, with the reaction advance, it is possible that the most active sites in the formation of ethylene are more harmed by the deposition of coke, compromising the general conversion and the selectivity to this product, while the diethyl ether is privileged. There are not many papers dealing with acidity and catalytic activity in layered silicates, essentially because they are not acidic materials by nature. However, samples of H-[Al]-magadiite (Si/Al = 9) were tested in the ethanol dehydration reaction and showed ca. 80% conversion and 80% of ethylene selectivity also at 350 °C [10]. As seen, the H-[Al]-RUB-18 samples (Si/Al = 22 and 32) showed superior results, reaching slightly superior conversion (83%) and significantly larger selectivity to ethylene (92%) (Fig. 4 , Table 1). Even with higher aluminum incorporation, H-[Al]-magadiite has a smaller amount of accessible acidic sites than H-[Al]-RUB-18, in addition to showing weaker acidity [10]. Although both materials belong to the hydrated layered silicate family, they exhibit considerable structural differences, such as the lamella thickness and silanolate/silanol ratio, which may be responsible for these differences when heteroatoms are incorporated. Some zeolites prepared from Na-RUB-18 were also employed in the ethanol dehydration reaction, such as FER, MAZ, and MOR [54,55]. In these cases, even coming from a lamellar material, they are microporous catalysts with a high surface area and a large number of accessible strong acidic sites. FER and MAZ showed conversions and ethylene selectivities around 100% when tested at 350 °C [54]. In turn, MOR showed a conversion comparable to H-[Al]-RUB-18, around 75%, and much lower ethylene selectivity, 15%; but the reaction temperature was 150 °C [55]. It is widely known that under these conditions, the dehydration of ethanol to ethylene is not favored. When compared to the materials currently used in industry, the H-[Al]-RUB-18 catalysts presented a slightly lower activity. Al2O3 (BASF) shows 100% ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity at 350 °C, while ZSM-5 zeolite (Zeolyst) shows 92% ethanol conversion and 97% ethylene selectivity at 280 °C [56]. As already commented, this difference can be attributed to the fact that lamellar silicates have a lower surface area than these materials, as well as fewer acidic sites. 3.2 Structural characterization by DFT calculations The optimized structures of Na-RUB-18 and Na-[Al]-RUB-18 are shown in Fig. 5 . The primitive unit cell of the silicic material (Fig. 5a) presents the composition Na4Si16O32(OH)4·16H2O. Initially, the structure refinement showed two different silicon sites: silanol/silanolates (O3Si-OH/O3Si-O−) and siloxane (O3Si-OSi). These sites can be related, respectively, to the well-known Q3 and Q4 sites around −99 and −111 ppm in the Na-RUB-18 29Si-MAS-NMR spectrum (Fig. 3) [57,58]. First, Na-RUB-18 was optimized in its geometries and the results were used to simulate the Al models. During the experimental synthesis of Al-samples, the aluminum incorporation procedure was analyzed by 27Al-MAS-NMR, Fig. 3, to verify the presence and nature of the new aluminum sites. As commented before, a unique signal was found at ca. 58 ppm due to tetrahedrally coordinated sites and only in the case where large amounts of aluminum were used (Si/Al = 15), then, octahedral aluminum sites also appeared, indicated by the signal around 9 ppm (Fig. 3). Interestingly, when adding aluminum to magadiite, a signal at the same position was observed; 2D-3QMAS-NMR experiments showed that it may be related to a hydrated site, that is, located on the lamella surface [6]. In the literature, however, post-synthesis aluminum incorporation into molecular sieves always leads to extra-lattice species [59–61]. Al-substituted materials were simulated using a Si/Al molar ratio of 15 in an attempt to include the two possible Al coordination observed experimentally (Fig. 5b-e). To define the nomenclature of simulated models in this work, the Si/Al ratio is written next to the Al, and the respective geometries (Td = tetrahedral and Oh = octahedral) are written in subscript with each site (aluminol = 1 and Al-framework = 2). First, tetrahedral aluminum was inserted into the two original silicon sites leading to an aluminol (Td1) (Fig. 5b) and a framework-Al (Td2) model (Fig. 5c), here called Na-[Al15T d 1]-RUB-18 and Na-[Al15T d 2]-RUB-18, respectively. In order to keep the charge balance after the replacement of tetravalent Si+4 by trivalent Al+3, the interlayer region received one more sodium cation than the original Na-RUB-18. The energetic comparison between Na-[AlT d 1]- and Na-[AlT d 2]-RUB-18 showed that the formation of framework-Al has the lowest electronic energy, with a difference of 10.95 kJ.mol−1 concerning to the formation of the aluminol. Similar tests were performed for octahedral aluminum, adding two more water molecules around the aluminol (Fig. 5d, Na-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18) and the framework-Al (Fig. 5e, Na-[Al15O h 2]-RUB-18). As previously described, experimental data had already indicated that these geometries were noticed in surface aluminum sites [6,55], similar to the aluminol model. As can be seen, water molecules kept coordinated with these groups, while the framework-Al sites did not accept to change into octahedral geometry. Therefore, the favorable Al-structures for this study are the framework-Al for tetrahedrally coordinated sites (Na-[AlT d 2]-RUB-18, Fig. 5c) and the aluminol for octahedrally coordinated sites (Na-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18, Fig. 5d). Table 2 shows the optimized parameters for each selected Al-structure. Their respective simulated XRD patterns were plotted in Fig. 6 and some (h k l) assignments were displayed in Table S1. Compared to optimized Na-RUB-18, the parameters a and b are slightly increased by 0.11 Å (1.5% of relative error, approximately) from the Na-RUB-18 to the aluminum forms. The α and β angles of Al-compounds also showed a difference of up to 1.0° (1.2% of relative error) from the silicic structure. Basal spacing presented a slight decrease in Na-[Al15T d 2]-RUB-18 (−1.15% of relative error), while a small increase was observed in Na-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18 (1.79% of relative error). This caused a small displacement of d002 peaks in the simulated XRD, from 7.89° (Na-RUB-18) to 7.80° (Al15Oh1) and 7.9° 2θ (Al15Td2), respectively. The assignment of other diffraction peaks (d 004 – d 108 ) established a good similarity between the Al-substituted structures. The agreement between simulated XRD patterns of Na-RUB-18 and the Al-structures with a Si/Al molar ratios of 30 and 60 is as good as with the sample with Si/Al molar ratio of 15 (Fig. 2). As seen in previous works [9,55], aluminum incorporation into Na-RUB-18 lamella does not lead to any amorphization or modification of the crystalline structure, an outcome corroborated by the morphology and dimensions of the plate-like crystals when analyzed by SEM (Fig. S1). 3.3 Investigation of ethanol dehydration by ci-neb calculations Using the most favorable aluminum sites in layered Na-RUB-18 determined above, the surfaces of H-RUB-18 (Fig. 7 a) and H-[Al]-RUB-18 (Fig. 7b-d) were simulated. Single-layer models were used in supercells 2 × 2 × 1 which are composed of 32 silicon atoms. For Si/Al molar ratios equal to 15 and 30, the surfaces of tetrahedral aluminum contained 2 and 1 aluminum sites, respectively. Thus, the acidic forms were obtained with the replacement of sodium cations by protons in the silanolate groups. In addition, extra hydrogen was inserted into each surface to neutralize the final charge. This proton was placed around the oxygen atoms: Al-O(H)-SiOH (Figs. 7b and 7c) and Si-O(H)-AlOH (Fig. 7d). In the case of the octahedral aluminum site, found in the sample with a Si/Al molar ratio of 15, the water molecules were removed because all the catalysts were treated at 250 °C before the NH3 thermoprogrammed desorption and the ethanol dehydration reaction. Although experimental samples with Si/Al ratio 15 presented aluminum atoms with tetrahedral and octahedral geometries, each site was simulated separately to better describe the behavior of ethanol molecules without interference from different sites on the same surface. The structures involved in the R3 and R4 reactions were optimized with the convergence of the forces of their atomic positions fixing a vacuum in the c parameter with a value of 25.0 Å and keeping a and b parameters and the angles as those shown in Table 2. For the catalytic process, the electronic activation energies for the direct and reverse reactions and the minimum energy path (MEP) for ethanol dehydration were calculated. The reactants, transition states, and products were described for each step, which is shown below. 3.3.1 Step 1 – water elimination For step 1, ethanol was initially adsorbed in each surface by hydrogen bonds. In the case of H-RUB-18, the interaction occurred in the silanol groups (Fig. 8 a). After that, a water molecule was formed by the hydrogen atom of the surface and the hydroxyl group of the molecule, leading to an interacting carbocation as a transition state (Fig. 8b). Thus, the alkyl group quickly binds to the oxygen of the silanolate group to form an ethoxide on the catalyst surface as a product of this step (Fig. 8c). In the case of H-[Al]-RUB-18 catalysts, the interaction between the ethanol molecule and the surface occurred through the extra proton. For the H-[Al15T d 2]-RUB-18, the ethanol molecule (Fig. 9 a) was adsorbed so that the ethyl group remained closer to the edge of the surface. With the elimination of the water molecule (Fig. 9b) the ethoxide group formed was positioned in the horizontal direction, parallel to the other slioxane groups (Fig. 9c). This behavior was noted for both materials with the Al-framework sites, that is, with Si/Al ratios 15 and 30, respectively. Contrary, the interaction between respective alcohol molecules and aluminol sites (H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18) was different from these on Al-framework. Despite the presence of an extra acidic site on the edge of the surface, the geometry optimization showed the ethyl group of the adsorbed ethanol (Fig. 10 a) in the perpendicular orientation to the siloxane groups. After the transition state (Fig. 10b), the geometry optimization of the products showed the ethoxide in the other direction, parallel to the position of the hydroxyl groups of H-[AlO h 1]-RUB-18 (Fig. 10c). To complete the picture, the ethanol dehydration was also simulated in the hydroxyl of the aluminol sites (here named H-[AlO h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH) to evaluate the catalytic contribution of this group, if any. Similar to the silanol test, the calculations showed an interaction between the hydroxyl of aluminol and the initial alcohol molecules (Fig. 11 a), which leads to the migration of hydrogen to form water (Fig. 11b) and then to the formation of chemical bonding of the ethyl group to the surface (Fig. 11c). The MEP for step 1 was plotted in Fig. 12 . As can be seen, the electronic activation energy for the direct reaction in the H-RUB-18 and H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH are 251.45 kJ.mol−1 and 320.22 kJ.mol−1, respectively, where hydroxyl groups were responsible for each catalytic reaction. However, the energetic barriers decreased for the Al-substituted compounds which used the extra proton inserted into the surface. Both sites of the H-[Al15]-RUB-18 surfaces showed closer activation energies (Td2 = 233.60 kJ.mol−1 and Oh1 = 225.46 kJ.mol−1, respectively), and the H-[Al30T d 2]-RUB-18 had the lowest value of all (210.52 kJ.mol−1). The comparison of activation energies in this part of the reaction already evidences that the presence of aluminum improves the properties of the catalyst once the extra proton has been identified, offering a more promising structure for this step. In any case, the silanol groups are also capable of acting on the dehydration of ethanol, as shown by the experimental data (Fig. 4, Table 1) and by the reaction models (Fig. 8). However, the same catalytic efficiency cannot be stated for the hydroxyl group of aluminol. Moreover, the comparison of each final image showed that the products with the lowest electronic energy occurred in the H-RUB-18 and H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH. The energy difference between these surfaces and the other catalysts was approximately 25.0 kJ.mol−1. However, this step forms only an intermediate ethoxide on the surface. In terms of kinetic properties, the lower the electronic energy of this respective intermediate, the more time the structure keeps on this stage. So, at the end of step 1, it is also possible to conclude that there is an additional energetic difficulty in the H-RUB-18 and H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH catalysts to go to the next step. 3.3.2 Step 2 – ethylene formation For step 2, ethylene was formed by the migration of one of the hydrogen atoms from the CH3 terminal group to the oxygen atom of the surface. In the case of the H-RUB-18, with the slight inclination of the ethyl group (Fig. 13 a) the proton translated to the oxygen atom that was initially bonded to carbon (Fig. 13b). Thus, ethylene is produced keeping an intermolecular interaction with the proton (Fig. 13c). Contrary, for ethoxide formed in the Al-framework sites (Fig. 14 a), the proton migration occurred in the other available oxygen atom bonded to aluminum (Fig. 14b). After that, the product showed the organic molecule closer to the surface (Fig. 14c). Again, models with Si/Al molar ratio 30 had the same behavior presented for Si/Al molar ratio 15. In the case of H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18, the alkyl group was accommodated so that the terminal -CH3 moved further away from the other oxygen atoms of the aluminol sites (Fig. 15 a). Therefore, the proton returned to the same oxygen atom that formed the ethoxide (Fig. 15b), where the ethylene molecule kept the intermolecular interaction (Fig. 15c). In the case of H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH, the hydroxyl group behaved similarly to the silanol group of H-RUB-18 (Fig. 16 a). The only oxygen atom capable of receiving the proton was the one bonded to the ethyl group (Fig. 16b). Thus, the product showed the return of the hydroxyl terminal group of aluminol sites (Fig. 16c). To understand the use of the extra proton in the formation of intermediates between the two reaction steps, the availability of sites for proton migration on surfaces with Al-substituted atom for H-[Al15T d 2]-RUB-18 and H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18 surfaces are better analyzed in Fig. 17 . As can be seen, the shorter hydrogen bonds between the CH3 group and oxygen atoms of the Al-framework site (Fig. 17a) was 2.34 Å, while the aluminol sites presented hydrogen bonds between 2.87 Å and 3.48 Å (Fig. 17b). In addition, another hydrogen bond occurred between hydroxyl groups of aluminol and silanol (1.67 Å). This caused a structural difficulty to accommodate adequately the organic species, leading to a product of Fig. 15c. After the structural analysis, the MEP of the models described in Figs. 12-14 were plotted in Fig. 18 . In this step, the large difference in electron activation energy between hydroxyl groups (H-RUB-18 and H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH, respectively) and those with Al-substituted using an extra proton is clearly noticeable. While the silicic form and aluminol sites showed energies of 214.58 kJ.mol−1 and 248.75 kJ.mol−1 in direct reaction, respectively, the other models presented all energies lower than 150 kJ.mol−1. In addition, the electronic energies of the product, identified by the final point of each energy plot in Fig. 18, were also smaller for catalysts with aluminum atoms than H-RUB-18. For MEP calculations, the higher the electronic energy of the final point plotted of a system, the lower its stability. This comparison reinforces that aluminum is indeed responsible for the increase in ethylene formation in Al-catalysts. For the reaction simulated in the extra proton site in the H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18, the MEP showed increased energy barriers (225.46 kJ.mol−1 and 120.50 kJ.mol−1 for direct and reverse order, respectively), in comparison to framework-Al sites. This suggests that the additional energetic difficulty for the formation of ethylene over aluminol sites is related to the possible hydrogen bonds described in Fig. 15. Although the aluminol site is not as favorable for acidic catalysis as framework Al, its catalytic contribution with the extra proton is still more relevant to the reaction than those occurred in hydroxyl groups, because the energy barrier of H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18 was approximately 65.0 kJ.mol−1 lower than H-RUB-18 and approximately 100 kJ.mol−1 lower than H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH. This is also suggested by the slightly superior conversion presented by H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 in relation to H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18, which does not have octahedral aluminum sites. The comparison between AlTd-models indicates a similar behavior for catalysts H-[Al15T d 2]-RUB-18 and H-[Al30T d 2]-RUB-18, where the electronic energies for direct reaction were 111.60 kJ.mol−1 and 106.08 kJ.mol−1, respectively. As previously discussed, the interaction between the ethoxide group and the oxygen atoms of framework-Al offered similar transition states and products for these Si/Al molar ratios. It is important to emphasize that, although the experimental sample H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 presents also octahedral sites, the content of framework-AlTd sites is similar in both samples: Si/AlTd of 29 (H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18) and 32 (H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18), respectively. That already suggested that AlOh did not play any outstanding role in the dehydration of ethanol, which was reinforced by the MEP analysis in the DFT calculations. 4 Conclusions The acidic RUB-18 samples showed good performances in the ethanol dehydration reaction. The best results were found for the H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18 and H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18 catalysts: 83 and 80% conversion, respectively, and 92% of ethylene selectivity. These samples presented a higher aluminum content and, as verified, more accessible acidic sites. Thus, aluminum incorporation is essential for the generation of acidic centers, since H-RUB-18 presented a significantly poorer performance. Finally, the H-[Al]-RUB-18 catalysts even showed better results over the ethanol dehydration reaction than their lamellar relative, the H-[Al]-magadiite. The Na-[Al]-RUB-18 structure models showed that the presence of tetrahedral aluminum is favorable in framework-Al sites, while the octahedral geometries are found only on the surface, forming aluminol sites. Both species are related to the original siloxane and silanol groups in the pure silica material, respectively. After the Al-substitution and the addition of a sodium cation to neutralize the final charge, the simulated XRD patterns did not present significant changes in the main diffraction peaks when compared to Na-RUB-18. A good agreement was found between the simulation proposals and the experimental results that additionally pointed to a limit of framework-Al incorporation, around the Si/Al molar ratio of 30. When higher aluminum contents were added to the synthesis mixture, aluminol sites were generated. The simulations indicated that ethanol dehydration reaction performed over hydroxyl groups in the H-RUB-18 and H-[Al15O h 1]-RUB-18-AlOH surfaces showed the highest electronic energy reactions, which corroborates that the presence of aluminum sites in the structure improves the catalytic performance due the presence of the extra proton. For the H-[Al]-RUB-18 samples, framework-Al presented lower electronic barriers to the ethanol dehydration reaction when compared to aluminol sites. However, the surface with Si/Al ratio equal to 30 offered the best energetic conditions to perform the ethanol dehydration reaction: the lowest electronic energies in both steps, the formation of the intermediate with the highest electronic energy in step 1, and the lowest electronic energy in the final product of step 2. These results also support the experimental analysis. H-[Al30_32]-RUB-18 sample is catalytically comparable to H-[Al15_22]-RUB-18, with lower aluminum content and only tetrahedral framework-Al sites. coredata.dc:description: Functional acidic sites can be generated in the structure of layered silicates by the isomorphic substitution of silicon by aluminum atoms, leading to suitable heterogeneous catalysts. H-[Al]-RUB-18 samples were synthesized with Si/Al molar ratios of 15, 30, and 60. Experimental characterizations showed that two different aluminum sites were obtained: one tetrahedrally coordinated (framework-Al), very similar to those found in microporous zeolites; and the other octahedrally coordinated, analogous to silanol groups (hydrated aluminol sites). Computational simulations based on Density Functional Theory (DFT) were used to test the atomic positions of these aluminum sites and confirmed, in terms of electronic energies, the tetrahedral and octahedral positions already predicted in the experimental characterizations. In addition, ethanol dehydration reaction was used to probe the acidic sites and evaluate the performance of the different [Al]-RUB-18 samples. Although a widely known reaction for zeolites and other porous solids, the chemical analysis in this work indicated that the Al-substituted layered silicates are promising candidates to be used in heterogeneous catalysis. The experimental catalytic data showed that the presence of aluminum atoms improved the reaction conversion. Moreover, MEP calculations also presented, in each step of ethanol dehydration, Alframework sites with the lowest electronic energy barriers.
coredata.dc:title: The behavior of aluminum sites in H-[Al]-RUB-18 catalysts: A theoretical-experimental investigation
